text: Kansas v. Marsh, 548 U.S. 163 (2006), is a United States Supreme Court case in which the Court held that a Kansas death penalty statute was consistent with the United States Constitution. The statute in question provided for a death sentence when the aggravating factors and mitigating factors were of equal weight.The Supreme Court, 2005 Term — Leading Cases, 120 Harv. L. Rev. 144 (2006). == See also == * List of United States Supreme Court decisions on capital punishment ==References== ==External links== * Category:United States Supreme Court cases Category:United States Supreme Court cases of the Roberts Court Category:Cruel and Unusual Punishment Clause and death penalty case law Category:Capital punishment in Kansas Category:2006 in United States case law
title: Kansas v. Marsh
